body:
The iDAI.world is a grown structure that has developed over the last years. It is made up of different systems that have been developed in cooperation with many partners. The term iDAI.world is an overarching infrastructure that connects systems on archives, library collections, rich photographic libraries, geographic data, place names, chronological terms, bibliographical references, electronic publications, and thesauri.Together they form comprehensive infrastructure for research in Archaeology and neighboring fields of study. Further information is provided below.

The iDAI.world is also constantly evolving. It is a permanent beta system with clear goals and visions and continuously developing new tools.

tiles.headline: iDAI.objects/Arachne
tiles.text: iDAI.objects also known as Arachne, is an online image database that combines descriptions, preservation state, dating, location, and literature on the object. Other related datasets are linked with the dataset and overarching categories as well.

tiles.headline: iDAI.bibliography/Zenon
tiles.text: iDAI.bibliography is a search engine for archaeological literature, allowing the user to find monographs, journals, articles and reviews. Aside from being helpful in finding literature on a certain topic, it also functions as a catalog for all of the libraries of the DAI.

tiles.headline: iDAI.field
tiles.text: iDAI.field is a database for excavation documentation. Areas, trenches, finds and sites can be marked with polygons and layers with drawings or photographs can be stacked upon each other. The datasets are connected to the plans and a matrix is also automatically generated.

tiles.headline: iDAI.gazetteer
tiles.text: Aside from assigning coordinates to place names, it also lists the several different names of a place and shows related places. The parent and child locations are also linked to the datasets as are datasets in iDAI.objects, iDAI.bibliography and Pelagios.

tiles.headline: iDAI.chronontology
tiles.text: Connecting descriptive period terms to fixed datings and areas, for which the chronological term is used. The previous and following periods are shown, as are related datings, subcategories, the type material that is described by the chronological term and a description of the period.

tiles.headline: iDAI.archives
tiles.text: The archival holdings of the DAI make up an important research basis for current archaeological scholarship as well as for the institute’s history, the history of archaeology and its protagonists as well as history of sciences in general.

tiles.headline: iDAI.geoserver
tiles.text: iDAI.geoserver is an open data platform for sharing geospatial data and maps. It includes open GIS datasets in layer, maps and documents relating to cultural heritage and archaeology. The data can be edited by registered users and thus be shared with other researchers.

tiles.headline: IANUS
tiles.text: IANUS was developed within a project aiming to create a national research data structure for classical studies and archaeology. At the moment, IANUS works with partners from the Cultural Heritage Ministries, museums and universities to establish IANUS as a standard in classical studies in Germany.

tiles.headline: iDAI.thesauri
tiles.text: iDAI.thesauri combines all of the DAI’s thesauri, giving labels to concepts and showing alternative terms to labels in various languages.

tiles.headline: iDAI.publications/books
tiles.text: As a subpage of iDAI.publications, iDAI.books compiles all of the DAI’s digitally published monographs and series in an open access environment. Together with iDAI.bibliography and iDAI.publications/journals, it forms the iDAI’s literature research infrastructure.

tiles.headline: iDAI.publications/journals
tiles.text: As a subpage of iDAI.publications, iDAI.journals compiles all of the DAI’s digitally published journals in an open access environment. Together with iDAI.bibliography and iDAI.publications/books, it forms the DAI’s literature research infrastructure.

tiles.headline: iDAI.repo
tiles.text: iDAI.repo makes it possible to publish research data in accordance with the FAIR principles with persistent identifiers, thereby making it citable and reusable.
